Micro and nano-size pores of clay minerals in shale reservoirs: Implication for the accumulation of shale gas
Chen Shangbin a,b,⁎, Han Yufu b, Fu Changqin b, Zhang han b, Zhu Yanming a,b, Zuo Zhaoxi b a Key Laboratory of Coalbed Methane Resources and Reservoir Formation Process of the Ministry of Education, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou 221116, China b School of Resources and Earth Science, China University of Mining and Technology, Xuzhou, 221116, China

Article history: Received 25 April 2016 Received in revised form 27 June 2016 Accepted 29 June 2016 Available online 09 July 2016
Editor: Dr. B. Jones
A pore is an essential component of shale gas reservoirs. Clay minerals are the adsorption carrier second only to organic matter. This paper uses the organic maturity test, Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM), and X-ray Diffraction (XRD) to study the structure and effect of clay minerals on storing gas in shales. Results show thedepositional environment and organicmaturity influence the content and types of clayminerals aswell as their structure in the three types of sedimentary facies in China. Clayminerals developmulti-size pores which shrink to micro- and nano-size by close compaction during diagenesis. Micro- and nano-pores can be divided into six types: 1) interlayer, 2) intergranular, 3) pore and fracture in contact with organic matter, 4) pore and fracture in contact with other types of minerals, 5) dissolved and, 6) micro-cracks. The contribution of clayminerals to the presence of pores in shale is evident and the clay plane porosity can even reach 16%, close to the contribution of organic matter. The amount of clay minerals and pores displays a positive correlation. Clay minerals possess a strong adsorption which is affected by moisture and reservoir maturity. Different pore levels of clay minerals are mutually arranged, thus essentially producing distinct reservoir adsorption effects. Understanding the structural characteristics of micro- and nano-pores in clay minerals can provide a tool for the exploration and development of shale gas reservoirs.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Shale gas occurs in three distinct phases in the reservoirs: 1) free phase, 2) adsorption phase and, 3) dissolved phase (Jarvie et al., 2007). The free and adsorption phases constitute the principal occurrences of shale gas (Kang et al., 2010). The proportion of adsorbed gas in shale gas reservoirs is 20% to 85% (Curtis, 2002). The gas is mainly adsorbed on the surface of organic particles and clay minerals (Curtis, 2002; Bowker, 2003; Jarvie et al., 2007). The content of organic matter is only 3% in shale gas reservoirs, but is essential for generating adsorption. The formation of other minerals depends on the chemical composition of the reservoir rocks in which the clay minerals constitute 37% to 48% (Dong et al., 2010). The main clay minerals are variously layered chained-structure silicates. The special structure and physicochemical properties of clay minerals control in part the reservoir structure, its adsorption capacity and gas enrichment.
Clay minerals create important connections between inorganic and organic pores. Clays are important to the process of pore evolution and maturation in petroliferous basins. Clay minerals contain a massive amount of nano-pores (Nelson, 2009; Curtis et al., 2012; Yao et al., 2012), which mostly develop in interlayer and particle inter-cleavage

surfaces to produce space in the shale reservoir. Micro-cracks formed by the recrystallization of montmorillonite into illite, provide massive reservoir space and effective channels for shale gas transport and enrichment (Zhao andHe, 2012). Claymineral pores are themain contributors to shale gas reservoir space, especially in the low-mature and mature stage of reservoirs containing a low content of organic matter (Schettler and Parmoly, 1990; Hao et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2015). The nature and content of clay minerals varied with diagenesis leading to different pore structures and capacities of adsorption. The pore structures of a clay mineral within shale differ depending on the degree of evolution of the reservoir. Therefore, the clay mineral pores contribute differently to the formation of the reservoir pores. Meanwhile, their impact on the adsorption of methane in the shale reservoirs remains unclear.
Research experiments performed on clay minerals showed illite having the strongest capacity for methane adsorption which decreases rapidly when it contains water, because of the preferential adsorption of water over methane (Ross and Bustin, 2009). Other studies revealed that montmorillonite possess the largest adsorption capacity for methane (Ji et al., 2012a,b; Tang and Fan, 2014). The complex morphology and polytrophic structure of shale can readily produce a strong heterogeneity leading to varied types of clay minerals (Qiu, 1992). The influence of shale gas adsorption and reservoir quality by clay minerals involves characteristics of solid–liquid-gas phase, and the relationship
among them remains unclear. This hampers the fine characterization and evaluation of shale gas reservoirs and affects significantly a detailed resource evaluation. It is a key problem that needs to be solved urgently if one wants to understand the enrichment mechanism of shale gas reservoirs.

sections.heading: 2.1. Shale gas reservoirs in China
sections.text: China is ranked third country in theworld for the commercial development of shale gas, after the USA and Canada. In China, there are three types of organic-rich shales classified according to their depositional environments (Zou et al., 2011; Dong et al., 2012). The shales defined a marine facies, a marine-continental transitional facies and a continental facies. China is rich in shale gas resources and a 2012 preliminary assessment made by the Ministry of Land and Resources in China, estimated a recoverable resources exceeding 25 × 1012 m3 (Development project of shale gas in China, 2012). China has made breakthrough discoveries of shale gas resources in the three abovementioned sedimentary facies in several regions and geological periods. This includes the Paleozoic formations of the Sichuan Bain, Mesozoic formations of the North Sichuan Basin, Triassic formations of the Edors Basin and Carboniferous–Permian formations in Middle North China (Zou et al., 2011; Dong et al., 2012). The Fuling shale gas field in the Chongqing municipality was the first commercially developed shale gas basin in China (Guo and Zhang, 2014).

sections.heading: 2.2. Sampling
sections.text: We selected different types of black shale samples from various sites, namely from the following formations exposed in China: the Qiongzhusi Formation (Fm.) (Є1q), the Longmaxi Fm. (S1l), the Taiyuanzu Fm. (C2−P1t), the Yanchang Fm. (T3y), which are important shale gas reservoirs in China (Fig. 1). The samples were collected from drillcores and outcrops. Eight-one samples were selected from the Qiongzhusi Fm. in the Yangtze area and come from 8 outcrops and one drill site. Another 83 samples were gathered from the Yangtze area, specifically from the Longmaxi Fm. which includes 6 outcrops. Fifty samples were collected from the Taiyuan Fm. within the Qinshui Basin and were sourced from 11 drill sites. Finally, 10 samples from the Erdos Basin (Yanchang Fm.) were selected from 3 outcrops (Fig. 1). The samples collected from outcrops were affected by a certain degree of weathering. The fresh profiles or outcrops were found as far as possible in the process of sample collection, such as some engineering excavation sites. And the test data was suggested that there is no significant difference in the types of clay mineral between drillcores and outcrops in the same formation. Therefore, all samples and results presentedwere fine and have no effect on the arrival at a conclusion.

sections.heading: 2.3. Experimental methods
sections.text:
In this study, the vitrinite reflectance (Ro)wasmeasuredwith a Leitz microphotometer, and the analyses were performed at the Key Laboratory of Coalbed Methane Resources and Reservoir Formation Process of the Ministry of Education (CUMT).
X-ray Diffraction (XRD) was used to identify the mineral composition, and this analysis was performed at the Experiment Research Center of East China Brach (SINOPEC). The experimental temperature and humidity were 24 ℃ and 35%, respectively. Quantitative phase analysis was performed by Rietveld refinement, with customized clay mineral structure models (Ufer et al., 2008).
Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM) was performed with a Quanta 200F equipped with an energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS) on surfaces prepared by Ar-ion milling. Secondary electron images and BSE images can provide important qualitative
information on the general locations of pores throughout the sample. These experiments were also conducted at a temperature of 24 °C and a humidity level of 35%.

sections.heading: 3.1. Results
sections.text: The vitrinite reflectance (Ro) and clay minerals content of the three types of the reservoirs test results are shown in Table 1. And combined types of clay minerals in the formation are shown in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Thermal maturity of shale gas reservoirs
sections.text: The vitrinite reflectance values of Yanchang Fm. were determined between 0.66% and 1.2%, which showed that the thermal maturity was at the low-mature stage (Ro N 0.5%) and mature stage (Ro b 1.2%). The Ro values of Taiyuan Fm. were determined between 1.2% and 2.4%, which showed that the thermal maturity was at the high-mature stage (Ro N 1.2%) and over-mature stage (Ro N 2.0%). The Ro values of Longmaxi Fm. and Qiongzhusi Fm. were determined between 1.5% and 3.5%, 2% and 4%, respectively, which showed that the thermal maturity was at the high-mature stage (Ro N 1.2%) and over-mature stage (Ro N 2.0%). The thermal maturity parameters suggest that the marine facies reservoir (Longmaxi Fm. and Qiongzhusi Fm.) and marine-continental transitional facies reservoir (Taiyuan Fm.) are in the (dry) gas generation window. The continental facies reservoir (Yanchang Fm.) is in the gas condensate and (moisture) gas generation window. In over-mature thermal stage, the source rock mainly generates dry gas based on the principle of methane accompanied with a small amount of gas condensate.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Clay minerals of shale gas reservoirs
sections.text:
Clay minerals were also favorable for the formation and development of the shale gas reservoir. A wealth of data was obtained for clay minerals in typical shale reservoirs representing the three types of sedimentary facies in China. Clayminerals present various compositions depending on their different depositional environments (Fig. 2). The results show that the Yanchang Fm., Taiyuan Fm., Longmaxi Fm. and Qiongzhusi Fm. have different clay minerals content, with a mean content of 51.69% (range 36.3%–80.7%), 61% (range 37.3%–98.5%), 40.13% (range 18%–64.5%) and 20.72% (range 3.7%–47.9%), respectively (Table 1). It is suggested that all samples contain clay minerals composed of illite (I), chlorite (Ch) and illite-montmorillonite (I/S) (Fig. 2). Illite–montmorillonite content is the main clay mineral composition in Yanchang Fm. and Taiyuan Fm., with the value of 56.34% and 46.95%, respectively. Illite (I) is the most common of the clay minerals in Longmaxi Fm. and Qiongzhusi Fm., and it has the highest content, with the value of 55.68% and 67.12%, respectively. The samples also contain kaolinite except Longmaxi Fm. and it has the highest kaolinite content in Taiyuan Fm. with the value of 36.42% for the regional geological features.
3.1.3. Morphology and classification of clay mineral pores in the shale gas reservoirs
Fig. 3 shows the claymineralmorphologies in shale reservoirs under the FE-SEM. Illite presents a flakemorphology, illite–montmorillonite is sheet-like and kaolinite forms irregular tabular overlays, and chlorite displays granular overlays under the SEM (Fig. 3A, B, C, D).
The shale reservoir pores were divided into intergranular, interparticle and organic matter varieties (Loucks et al., 2012), while the clay minerals develop the first two varieties. For the classification in shale, Chinese scholars substituted the organic matter by the microfissure variety (Yang et al., 2013; Yu, 2013; Wang et al., 2014a,b). The classification of clay minerals pores is too general compared to that established for organic matter pores. It cannot fully appraise the morphology, occurrence and contact relation of clay minerals which
contribute to create porosity in shale gas reservoirs. The role of clay minerals in the reservoir adsorption process is underestimated. The nanometer andmicron-size pore fissures associatedwith shale reservoir clay minerals are subdivided into 6 types: interlayered, intergranular, pore and fracture in contact with organic matter, pore and fracture in contact with other types of minerals, dissolved pore and micro-crack (Fig. 4). This classification combined with morphology characteristics of pores and the causes, can elaborate the contribution of multi-scale pore in clay minerals. Interlayered and intergranular pores are small in size and carry poor connectivity, the latter controlling the occurrence of shale gas. Contact pores and fissures not only provide reservoir space for shale gas but also determine the development of seepage and fracturing within the shale reservoir.

sections.heading: 3.2. Difference in clay minerals of shale gas reservoirs
sections.text:
The principal clayminerals in the Qiongzhusi Fm. and Longmaxi Fm. consist of illite and illite–montmorillonite. For the Taiyuan Fm., themain clay minerals are composed of kaolinite and illite–montmorillonite, whereas they consist of illite–montmorillonite in the Yanchang Fm. Terrigenous and authigenic clay minerals constitute two genetic types found in shales. Terrigenous clay minerals are produced by the weathering of outcrops and soils. At the low maturity stage (Ro b 0.5%), the diagenesis process has little influence on the composition of clay minerals in the shale, thus terrigenous clay minerals form the principal typewithminor authigenic clays. Authigenic clayminerals are generated by the recrystallization of other clay minerals during diagenesis including the crystallization of unstable montmorillonite and kaolinite into relatively stable illite–montmorillonite, stable illite and chlorite. The degree of conversion is affected by the maturity of the reservoir, the higher the maturity the more advanced the transformation. In addition, some new clay minerals were formed by the reaction of unstable minerals (such as volcanic ash) with water (Xu et al., 2003).
Various types of clay minerals occur in different depositional environments due to some factors, such as the input of terrestrial material (surface rocks and soils), the composition of riverwater and the climate. Within the same depositional environment, the evolution at sequence of clay minerals by diagenesis is strongly controlled by the thermal evolution of the sedimentary basin. Although the Qiongzhusi Fm. and Longmaxi Fm. display the same depositional environment, the two reservoirs present different types and content of clay minerals because
they experienced distinct diagenesis evolutions. During the initial deposition stage, clay minerals can reflect the original depositional environment of the shale. Geologists commonly use a clay minerals index to unearth the original depositional environment (Singer, 1984). With the developing diagenesis, the amount of unstable clay minerals decreases at the expense of stable clay minerals which increase gradually along a conversion sequence spurred by the thermal evolution of the basin (Xu et al., 2003). Therefore, diagenesis and depositional environment are two important factors controlling the types and combination of clay minerals in the shale reservoir.

sections.heading: 3.3. Structure of clay minerals
sections.text: There are several types and combinations of clay minerals in a shale reservoir. During the diagenesis process, the clay minerals can develop different morphologies, multi-scale micro-pores and cause fissures in the shale reservoir because of their special structure and physicochemical properties. Floccules are clumps of electrostatically charged clay flakes that sink toward the sea floor in ion-enriched seawater; the floccule can form a “cardhouse” structure of individual edge-face- or edge-edge-oriented flakes and/or domains of face-face-oriented flakes (O'Brien, 1971, 1972; Bennett et al., 1991). O'Brien and Slatt (1990) found examples in the geological column of pores in flocculent clay minerals from micro-bedded shales. However, it is difficult to explain how these open pores were preserved after they underwent burial and diagenesis for hundreds millions of years. In fact, these types of pores are clay minerals interlayer pores. Loucks and Ruppel (2007) showed the existence of intergranular pores between clay and brittle minerals (such as quartz, feldspar, and carbonate minerals), and the presence of intra-granular pores within the clay minerals cleavage planes. Yang et al. (2013) identified two principal pore types, e.g. intercrystalline pores and particle surface pores in illite from Early Paleozoic shale reservoirs.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Dimension of clay mineral pores
sections.text:
The size of clay mineral pores is a key subject of the shale gas research. The shale gas exits as different phase states from multidimensional pores in clayminerals. The configuration of pores provides the condition for converting between the free and adsorption phases. The claymineral pore size varies between themicrometer and nanometer scalewith littlemillimeter dimension. Keller and Staudt (2005) have classified the pores into ultra-micro-pore (b0.6 nm), micro-pore (0.6 to
2 nm), meso-pore (2 to 50 nm), macro-pore (50 nm to 2 μm), capillary pore (2 to 50 μm) and giant capillary pore (N50 μm). The classification corresponds to the one used by the IUPAC.
The physical and chemical properties of clay minerals confer a special layered structure. Different types of clay minerals display distinct spacing of the interlayered domains. The interlayered domains ofmontmorillonite can expand to 1.7 nmwhen in contact with water, whereas it is fixed at 1 nm for illite (Xiong, 1983). The diameter of a methane molecule is only 0.38 nm. So the molecule can be dissolved in water or stored in interlayered domain by ionic bonding. These pores are mainly ultra-micro-pores and micro-pores. However, the meso-pores and macro-pores constitute the dominant pores of clay minerals. They formed between sheets of clays by mutual support, filling or corrosion.
They are different from organic matter pores. Furthermore, some small cracks were formed at the contact of clay minerals and organic matter or clay minerals and brittle minerals (such as quartz and feldspar). These small fractures can have micron-size lengths and constitute good channels connecting very small pores in a shale reservoir. These fractures are well developed in the Yanchang Fm. However, highmaturity (Ro b 2.0%) reservoirs, such as the Qiongzhusi Fm. and Longmaxi Fm., are fracture-poor. The reason is that the pores are reduced by sediment compaction which gets stronger with increasing depth of burial (Milliken et al., 2013). The capillary pores can develop in the particle inter-cleavage surfaces. Clay minerals originally formed in larger pores in which they can grow more freely and evolve stable crystal forms.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Morphology of clay mineral pores
sections.text:
Clays are important minerals of sedimentary rocks. In sandstone, clay minerals crystallize in pores as interstitial material. The clay minerals can crystallize in a more stable structure since big-size pores favor the growth of clayminerals. Themorphology of illite in sandstones presents fiber-like (fibrous) and hair filament aspects under the SEM. Illite–montmorillonite shows aggregates of flakes, short filaments, honeycomb-like and palmate. Kaolinite presents a book-like structure and exhibits a hexagonal tabular form. Chlorite shows petal, leaf-like, and fluff sphere-like shapes (Fig. 3). In shales, illite presents a flake morphology. Illite–montmorillonite is sheet-like and kaolinite forms irregular tabular overlays. Chlorite displays granular overlays under the SEM (Fig. 3). The different morphologies were influenced by the diagenetic process which involves principally the compaction and recrystallization of clay minerals. The pore size in shales rapidly decreases through strong compaction when water is expelled. The pores located between the clay minerals are compressed. The clay minerals having a definite shape present a directional alignment. The clay minerals showed limited growth during their recrystallization, and cannot develop stable crystal forms. The pore size was diminished. Therefore, in sandstones, the clay minerals are associated with pores located between brittle minerals, whereas in shales, they reflect the capacity of the reservoir and the degree of pore development.
It is difficult to analyze the pore size of clay minerals because the various types of shale (structure, texture) generate numerous complications. Therefore, the study of pure clayminerals can reflect the pore size more accurately. The morphology of pure illite presents twistedtortuousunder the SEM. Illite–montmorillonite shows silk like and flared. Chlorite shows aggregates of tabular. The result from Ji et al. (2012a,b) from pure clay minerals showed that the illite and chlorite pores are similar, and are mainly meso–macro-pore (20 to 100 nm) with a mean value at 55 nm. Illite–montmorillonite always contains 6 nm micro–meso-pores and 20 to 100 nm meso–macro-pores, with a mean value at 3.5 nm and 55 nm, respectively. The kaolinite pores are chiefly meso–macro-pore (10 to 70 nm), with modes at 16 nm and 30 to 60 nm. Therefore, the illite, chlorite, and kaolinite pores are mainly meso–macro-pores except for illite–montmorillonite. Moreover there are a mass of micro-pores in clay minerals, and micro–nano pores form the pore system of pure clay minerals. Nano-pores are the most abundant size in clay minerals and present the highest capability to develop gas reservoirs. Open-type nano-pores, can especially increase the shale reservoir permeability and the desorption capacity of shale gas, thus augmenting the production from shale gas (Chen et al., 2012).
Studies of pure clay mineral pores indicated illite developing interlayered and intergranular pores, illite–montmorillonite developing interlayered and intergranular pores accompanied by fissures and, kaolinite and chlorite characterized by intergranular pores (Ji et al.,

Contact pores and fractures (including pores and fractures in contact with organic matter or other types of minerals) develop between clay minerals and organic matter or brittle minerals. These pores and fractures formed from untight contact between minerals lead to edges stagger ofminerals for stress uneven. sections.heading: 3.4. The implication of clay minerals into the accumulation of shale gas
3.4.1. Contribution of clay mineral pores to the shale gas reservoir
sections.text:
Shale gas mainly stored on the surface of organic matter or clay particles in adsorbed state and free state (Curtis, 2002; Bowker, 2003; Jarvie et al., 2007). Shale gas is associated with organic matter (Chalmers and Bustin, 2008; Zhang et al., 2012, 2013), but the contribution of clay minerals is less clear. The characteristics of organic matter in shale, such as contents, types, and maturity, are main factors that influence the shale gas adsorption contents (Ross and Bustin, 2007). Schettler and Parmoly (1990) believed methane was distributed on the surface of illite and adsorbed in kerogen. Ross and Bustin (2008) concluded clay minerals have a high pore volume and large specific surface areas with a greater capacity of adsorption.
Samples collected form the Longmaxi Fm. in the Yangzi area were analyzed to establish the contribution of clay minerals pores to the formation of shale reservoirs. Organic matter pores were examined for comparison (Fig. 5). The surface porosity can be used to ascertain the mineral porosity. We collected samples from different sites of the Lonmaxi Fm. to ensure randomness (Here, “random” means select SEM photo with clay minerals and organic matters pores randomly, not choose special SEM photo.). The surface porosity of organic matter ranges from 14.72% to 19.67%, with an average value of 16.81%. The surface porosity of clayminerals varies from 9.84% to 23.1%, with a roughly similar average value of 16% and a large standard deviation of 4.78 (Table 2). The surface porosity values of clay minerals show a strong heterogeneity. This may be attributed to the fact that clay minerals act differently during diagenesis, whereas the organic matter pores are being more stable. Because in the digenesis process, clay mineral pores are easily affected by the compaction and transformation of clay mineral (Fu et al., 2015), and organic matter pores are mainly affected by thermal effect and its hydrocarbon-generating. The pore size affects the occurrence of methane. When analyzing the relation between shale gas and clay mineral pores, the percentage of pore-bearing free gas is often underestimated (Curtis, 2002; Montgomery et al., 2005; Wang et al., 2011). The porosity in shale is defined by the proportion of pore volume over the shale volume and accurately reflects the space occupied by shale gas in a reservoir. The correlation between the porosity and clay minerals content can reveal the interaction of adsorbed and free gas in clay minerals. The Changxin 1well was the first exploratory shale gaswell in China (Guo et al., 2013; Chen et al., 2013), and the Longmaxi Fm. reservoir contained illite and illite–montmorillonite as the main clay minerals accompanied by a low amount of chlorite and kaolinite. The porosity and claymineral contents define a good positive linear correlation (R2 = 0.92), whereas there is also a good positive linear correlation between the porosity and the content of illite and illite–montmorillonite (R2 = 0.91 and 0.86, respectively) (Fig. 6). Wang et al. (2014a,b, 2015) put forward a matrix porosity equation including brittle mineral (Bri), organic matter (TOC), and clay mineral (Clay), and set up the physical mode of shale rock, such as:

sections.heading: 3.4.2. The adsorption effect of clay minerals
sections.text:
The adsorption of gas molecules on clay minerals is related to the occurrence of shale gas (Jarvie et al., 2007; Loucks and Ruppel, 2007). The adsorption capacity varies with the different types of clayminerals. Micro- and nano-size pores can provide space for methanemolecules. It is difficult to analyze the adsorption capacity of clay minerals in a shale reservoir, so the experiments were carried on pure clayminerals. There are uncertainties on the adsorption capacity of montmorillonite and illite (Ross and Bustin, 2009; Ji et al., 2012a; Tang and Fan, 2014). Montmorillonite has a larger interlayer and manifests complex ionic interactions and has a strong adsorption capacity for methane. However, the adsorption capacity of illite is due to the open space of chip layers by compacting. Studies have shownmontmorillonite possessing the strongest adsorption, but the clay is not commonly found in several Chinese reservoirs because of their high maturity, so we no longer discuss its influence here. The source of samples, the temperature during testing and the experimental conditions are important factors explaining the different adsorption capacities obtained by different researchers (Fig. 7). Pure clay minerals have a strong adsorption capacity which in turn is related to the type of clay minerals. Therefore, clay minerals in shale also have a certain adsorption capacity. Shale reservoirs and pure clayminerals differ by their content of brittleminerals and organic matter. Clay minerals present a large plasticity during diagenesis, but brittle minerals play a supporting role in the shale, because the brittle minerals have a low plasticity. So the compaction of clay minerals in shale is weaker than in pure clay minerals, and thus can preserve more pore space.

Adsorbedmethane is present on the surface of illite accompanied by less abundant kerogen (Schettler and Parmely, 1991; Cao et al., 2015). Clay minerals possess more micro- and nano-size pores increasing the specific surface area of particles. More surface area is associated with smaller pores, and thus more methane could be adsorbed. The issue of smaller and more pores is important as it relates to surface area, which people accustomed to conventional reservoir still don't quite always get (Moore, 2012a,b). Pure clay minerals have a strong capacity for adsorption, but clayminerals in shale are greatly affected by the evolution of the associated organic matter. Bowker (2007) determined clay minerals extracted from the Barnett shale did not absorb methane. Lu et al. (1995) demonstrated illite adsorption can produce space volume for gaswith loworganicmatter content. The interaction of clayminerals with organicmatterwillmodify the adsorption capacity of the clays. The degree of maturity of the shale reservoir alters the evolution of organic matter which in turn affects the clay minerals.

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Factors influencing the adsorption of clay minerals
sections.text:
3.4.3.1. Water content in clay minerals. The moisture content in shale rocks shows large variations. Clayminerals aremore affected by the content of moisture. Illite–montmorillonite, for example, has lipophilic– hydrophobic characteristics. Under hydrous conditions, clay minerals will adsorb water first and thus reduce the adsorption of methane. There is a competition between the adsorption of water and methane (Gasparik et al., 2012). Under water-saturated conditions the adsorption capacity of clay minerals is greatly reduced.
In a real geological environment, a shale reservoir often contains water and variations in reservoir water concentrations will alter the adsorption ability of the shale. Research showed that there is a negative correlation between the maximum adsorption capacity of shale and its water content (Liu and Wang, 2012). Clay minerals in shale adsorb water along films with some capillary water and movable water (Zhao, 2005; Hu et al., 2014). Therefore, when water forms film on the
surface of clay minerals, methane is probably adsorbed at the center of pores, or adsorbed on the water film. This process reduces the capacity of adsorption of clay minerals to a great extent (Teng, 2009). Li et al. (2015) investigated the adsorption of slit pores and tube pores in clay minerals present in soil. The authors revealed that the adsorption of methane onwater films in clay pores varied linearly with the equilibrium pressure under low pressure, whereas the adsorption reaches saturation at high pressure. There are two types of methane and water fluid systems in shale gas reservoirs. Themodeof action andmechanism has a difference in reservoir material acting between water and methane. Organic matter is lipophilic–hydrophobic, while clay minerals are hydrophitic–hydrophilic. When water and methane coexist in a reservoir, selective adsorption will occur until an energy balance is achieved (Li et al., 2014). However, adsorptionmodels based on these conditions have not been established.
3.4.3.2. Maturity of the reservoir. The composition of clay minerals varies according to the degree of reservoir evolution and to clays presenting different contents of pores. Reservoir maturity affects the adsorption of shale gas and the content and nature of clay minerals (Xu et al., 2003). The nature and composition of clay minerals differ during the various stages of the diagenesis process within the same depositional environment. The pressure increases with increasing depth of burial. The compaction of plastic clay minerals augments so the volume and amount of pores are reduced. In low maturity reservoirs, the capacity of generating hydrocarbons from organic matter is weak and the micro-pore content is low. When the compaction of clay minerals is small, a massive amount of clay mineral pores can be preserved, and methane is principally stored in clay minerals. Furthermore, microand nano-size pores constitute seepage channels for methane at low maturity (Yang et al., 2015). With increasing maturity, the amount of pores in organic matter grows, and the clay minerals pores are compacted. Organic matter pores are dominant, but the clay mineral pores provide space for shale gas and seepage channels
which cannot be neglected (Wang et al., 2014a,b). Montmorillonite, illite–montmorillonite and kaolinite are recrystallized into illite and chlorite during diagenesis. From this process, clayminerals show different adsorption capacities. Cai et al. (2009) suggested that the type and content of organic matter which is adsorbed by different clay minerals show large variations. There are complex relations between soluble organic matter and clay minerals in hydrocarbon source rocks. This is significant for the occurrence of shale gas and the calculation of reserves.
There are many influences affecting the adsorption of clay minerals, includingwater content, maturity, temperature and pressure. Clayminerals are more affected by the content of moisture. It is easy to form a complex function among three-phase in water, rock and gas. Meanwhile, clay mineral content and type are affected by the maturity of the reservoir. Therefore, this manuscript mainly discussed these two influences. In general, with the temperature growing, the adsorption ability of clay mineral reduces, while it is increasing with the press growing (Ji et al., 2012a,b).

sections.heading: 3.4.4. The reservoir storage effect
sections.text:
The reservoir storage effect of clayminerals is a synoptic reflection of micro- and nano-size pores and does influence the occurrence of shale gas, that is the ratio of adsorbed over free gas. The adsorption of shale gas generally involves 2 nm-size pores (Mosher et al., 2013), so the discussion of the adsorption effect of clay minerals will ignore the mesoand macro-pores. Clay minerals develop whereas massive micro-pores like organic matter. The development of pores is significantly dependent on the moisture content. The mechanism of gas accumulating in clay minerals is rather complicated. Different types of clay minerals are spatially overlain and jointly influence the pore structure of shale reservoirs. Clay minerals and organic matter can form an organic-clay complex that resulted from the interaction of organic–inorganic components (Cai et al., 2007).
The accumulation of methane in clay minerals is the result of the mutual connection and arrangement of micro- and nano-size pores. Free and adsorbed gas coexists in pores, and multi-size pores correspond to different formation phases of shale gas. The clay mineral pores can be divided into three levels.
The first level is the clay mineral edge adsorbed pore. Clay minerals have special layered and chained structures with H bond at the edge of ruptured sites. Physical adsorption can be generated by the interaction of the van der Waals force with the methane molecule, whereas the chemical adsorption can be produced by the interaction of covalent bonds with the methane molecule (Zhao and He, 2012). In this level, claymineral also adsorbswater.Watermolecular adsorbs in hydrophilic clay minerals, and high water contents are not conducive to methane adsorption. But in compaction stage and montmorillonite illitization stage, shale has lost most water. So water contents have a certain effect in high mature stage, but this influence cannot neglect. Clay minerals can adsorbmethane in ultra-micro tomicro-pore-size level but no technique can measure at this low level.
The inter-slice of clay minerals forms the second level. It is an important channel connecting adsorbed and free gas. At the early sedimentation stage, clay minerals are formed by the deposition of floccules. Well-crystallized clay minerals developed pores by direct contact from the edge to the surface, edge to edge, surface to surface. In high mature stage, these pores would reduce by compacting. But part of them can be preserved through mutual support by minerals. Water also can exist in clay mineral surface and edge, but the contents reduce. Methane probably dissolves in water in this level. These pores reach up ten of nanometers in size and are at the detection limit of SEM measurement.
The third level consists of pores several hundred of nanometers to several microns in size. Due to intense compaction, the clay porosity was diminished. The pores were also compacted but partially-layered clay minerals formed surface cleavage pore space along with weak
clay mineral interfaces due to tectonic forces. The fissures which produce by clay mineral water shirking are important seepage channels in lowmature stage. These pores constitute reservoir space and seepage channels for shale gas. For low water contents, it cannot influence this level. The mutual arrangement of these three pore levels is beneficial to the formation of different phases and the development of shale gas. The surface cleavage pores in clay minerals were not well developed in the Yanchang Fm. and Taiyuan Fm., but appeared in the Qiongzhusi Fm. and Longmaxi Fm. They are closely related to the types of clayminerals and the diagenetic process. The edge-adsorbed and inter-slice pores are the main contributors of clay mineral pores. These pore types are seldom investigated due to the limitations of the detection methods.
Slatt and O'Neal (2011) found a symbiotic pore type that is a clay mineral encapsulated (incorporated) by organic matter. These pores appear at space of mutual dispose inter clay minerals of stripping plane in shale. And such pores is found in the Longmaxi Fm. with highmature. The relations between organic matter and clayminerals are not evident. Organic matter pores constitute the main space in shale reservoirs and can exist in interlayered, surface and intergranular clay minerals defining complex organic-clay forms. Micro- and nano-size pores in clay minerals can be invaded by organic matter and absorb methane. However, the role of organic–clay complexes is still in dispute.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: (1) The principal clay minerals manifest great compositional and structural variations within the shale reservoirs of China. The diagenetic process and depositional environments play a role in the types and combinations of clay minerals. (2) Clay minerals develop an arrangement of multi-size micro- and nano-pores. Pores associated with clay minerals in shale reservoirs are divided into interlayered, intergranular, pore and fracture in contact with organic matter, pore and fracture in contact with other types of minerals and a dissolved type. (3) The surficial pore ratio of organic and clay minerals is similar; however, the organicmatter ismore stable than the clayminerals. The clay mineral pores in shale can make some contribution for shale gas reservoir. (4) The adsorption of methanemolecules by clay minerals is affected by moisture and the reservoir maturity. A mutual arrangement of multi-size clay mineral pores influences the shale gas reservoir. Methane occurred in three levels of clay mineral pores and clay minerals adsorbed gas at the edge of their structure. Free gas occurs in the intergranular and inter-cleavage surface pores.

metadata.abstractText: Editor: Dr. B. Jones A pore is an essential component of shale gas reservoirs. Clay minerals are the adsorption carrier second only to organic matter. This paper uses the organic maturity test, Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM), and X-ray Diffraction (XRD) to study the structure and effect of clay minerals on storing gas in shales. Results show thedepositional environment and organicmaturity influence the content and types of clayminerals aswell as their structure in the three types of sedimentary facies in China. Clayminerals developmulti-size pores which shrink to microand nano-size by close compaction during diagenesis. Microand nano-pores can be divided into six types: 1) interlayer, 2) intergranular, 3) pore and fracture in contact with organic matter, 4) pore and fracture in contact with other types of minerals, 5) dissolved and, 6) micro-cracks. The contribution of clayminerals to the presence of pores in shale is evident and the clay plane porosity can even reach 16%, close to the contribution of organic matter. The amount of clay minerals and pores displays a positive correlation. Clay minerals possess a strong adsorption which is affected by moisture and reservoir maturity. Different pore levels of clay minerals are mutually arranged, thus essentially producing distinct reservoir adsorption effects. Understanding the structural characteristics of microand nano-pores in clay minerals can provide a tool for the exploration and development of shale gas reservoirs. © 2016 Elsevier B.V.
